strings.washImageFiveCaption: Making analysis of the purified water
strings.capacityOne: Water treatment and distribution for 15,000 people for a maximum of 4 months according to ERU SOPs.
strings.washCapacityTextOne: Provide support in wash response operations through the IFRC shelter roster of trained professionals and partner National Societies.
strings.emergencyServicesSectionOne: Treatment (including filtration) and distribution of water up to 225,000 litres a day for a population of 15,000 people.
strings.emergencyServicesSectionTwo: Storage capacity of a maximum of 200,000 litres a day.
strings.emergencyServicesSectionThree: Basic sanitation for up to 5,000 people.
strings.emergencyServicesSectionFour: Distribution and trucking capacity for transport of treated water to dispersed populations, capacity of up to 75,000 litres a day.
strings.designedForItemOneLabel: Response to scattered populations, with a flexible approach due to a number of smaller treatment units, which can be split and set up as stand-alone units in different locations.
strings.designedForItemTwoLabel: Availability of local water sources is required.
strings.designedForItemThreeLabel: Possibility to set up nine different storage and distribution points. Preconditions are availability of flatbed trucks, fuel, road access.
strings.designedForItemFourLabel: Water treatment lines (catchment, filtration, chlorination, distribution, and delivery) are mobile and the number might vary from 3 to 5 (production from 45,000 to 75,000 liters/day).
strings.personnelCompositionValue: Team Leader, 1-2 WASH or Chemical Engineer, 1 Technician/Plumber, 1 Logistic/Admin/Finance
strings.variationTextOne: Depending on NS the number of water purification lines (from catchment to delivery to affected people) can vary from 3 to 5.
strings.variationTextTwo: This unit could also provide very basic sanitation and hygiene promotion activities to 5,000 people.
